snippet: In exchange for giving up control of his chemical arsenal, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said he would require the United States to stop arming the opposition, using President Obama’s own “red line” against him.
abstract: Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad, in exchange for giving up control of his chemical weapons arsenal, says he will require United States stop arming opposition, turning crisis to his advantage and using President Obama’s own 'red line' against him; Secretary of State John Kerry delivers blunt response, saying standard procedures for identifying and securing chemical weapons are too slow.

byline.contributor: Brian Stelter contributed reporting from New York; Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon; and Michael R. Gordon from Geneva.

lead_paragraph: In exchange for giving up control of his chemical arsenal, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said he would require the United States to stop arming the opposition, using President Obama’s own “red line” against him.
